comments.author: OmegaStarScream
comments.created_time: February 07, 2025, 07:07:10 PMLast edit: February 07, 2025, 08:26:56 PM by OmegaStarScream
comments.body: "If it have other wice"? I'm not sure I understand that part.If by taking "your investement to another level" means you're going to be investing more as well, then a hardware wallet is definitely what you should go for here.Now I'm assuming what you mean by "even my wife and children" can access is after you pass away, or in case of an emergency? If the meaning is that you want them to have access at all times, and use the wallet, then I'm not sure a hardware wallet is what you want here. Not if they'll be spending from it on a regular basis.

comments.author: BIT-BENDER
comments.body: You are taking the right step but I have to tell you this now, wallet alone can not completely secure you especially from very close people like your wife and children. You have a whole lot to play, even with the safest wallet when you are careless with your device, seed phrase and other details you are already very exposed.But in terms of wallet I prefer electrum cold wallet storage this can protect you especially from online predators

comments.author: Hatchy
comments.body: I'll recommend you go for a cold storage like Trezor.. or setting up an air gapped device using an old PC plus electrum to store your coins offline and away from the Internet. Don't bother storing your funds on centralized platforms as you should remember not your keys not your coins. They literally would give you a digit of your balance but they indirectly own your coins. Paper wallet is good but old and if not properly store might be lost to damage.. about sharing your BTC holding with family..Though it would get to a point where you have to tell someone you trust about your BTC holdings, for now I'll advice you keep it to your self for security reasons. Even though you trust your family so well, you can tell just your wife so she would be aware of such assets..

comments.body: There is no wallet that your family and heir can just simply access if you are no longer there, you have to give them your seed phrase, or prepare an inheritance strategy that works for you.Quote from: OfficialGratejoy on February 07, 2025, 07:03:18 PMCentralize exchange walletNot your keys, not your coins.Quote from: OfficialGratejoy on February 07, 2025, 07:03:18 PMPaper walletThis has been replaced by hardware wallets, so no need to use it. Since you are looking for long term storage, which should be a cold storage wallet, then a hardware wallet is what you need, dyor before buying a hardware wallet and buy only directly from the manufacturer.

comments.author: Charles-Tim
comments.body: Quote from: OfficialGratejoy on February 07, 2025, 07:03:18 PMI want to take my BTC investment to another level,so which of this wallet's listed bellow we serve me for a life time,that even my wife or children can access,if it goes other wice.This is not about the wallet that you are using, it is about your seed phrase which is used to access your coins. Make sure you protect the seed phrase. About wallets, the safest are paper wallet if you operate it offline, and wallet on airgapped devices. Next are reputed hardware wallets which are also secure. Centralized exchanges are not reliable. Not your key not your coin.

comments.author: coolcoinz
comments.body: Just don't keep it on exchanges!It depends on how much money you're investing. I always tell people that buying a hardware wallet for $100 is like buying a steel safe to hold a similar amount of money. Don't spend more than 10% of your investment on security or it will make no sense. If you hold $1k or less, don't waste time on hardware wallets just buy yourself a decent mobile wallet that allows you to store a seed phrase. Personally I use Electrum, but I've tried other options like Blue wallet. If you're investing more, like $10k+ get a hardware wallet. It's worth spending a few hundred to protect a few thousand, right?

comments.author: EFS
comments.body: As a Bitcoin wallet I would definitely prefer Electrum. You can also teach your family how to use it, so they will know how to access the coins when you're not around. If you're not investing in altcoins, Electrum would be sufficient as a Bitcoin wallet. A hardware wallet is not an absolute necessity. Don't forget to back up your Electrum wallet to a flash drive or a hard disk. Don't leave your funds on central exchanges, as there's no secure side to that. In the long term, you most likely won't have access to that money.

comments.author: X-ray
comments.body: for me personally, hardware wallet for sending BTC, or anything related to on chain activity.paper wallet is for when you just want to store your BTC but want it to not be connected to internet to ensure security that it won't get leaked.because even hardware wallet might have vulnerability, if i remember correctly certain hardware wallet gives feature to back up seed phrase in their cloud storage which just seems weird to me, we basically giving password to stranger to access our asset.but honestly, even with desktop wallet, it already suffice.
